docs.lead_paragraph: The general manager was proud to report that Dan Quayle had once eaten in his restaurant, and so had George Bush as Vice President. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, he said, was a regular, and these days so is James Carville, the Clinton campaign strategist. John Norris wasn't necessarily name-dropping. Morton's steak restaurant in Georgetown has been a magnet for years to Washington's leading political figures.

headline.main: On the Menu, Steak Bucks Trend
